conclusion: To determine the car's acceleration, analyze the position-time graph.
The graph is a position-time graph showing x as a function of t, but actually represents x/t versus t.
The graph shows a straight line with a positive slope, indicating x/t is increasing linearly with time.
If x/t is a linear function of t, it implies velocity v = dx/dt is constant.
The slope of the line in the graph gives the velocity.
The slope is calculated as rise over run: rise is 10 m/s, run is 2 s.
The slope (velocity) is 10 m/s divided by 2 s, which is 5 m/s².
Since velocity is constant, acceleration a is zero.
Acceleration is the rate of change of velocity with respect to time; if velocity is constant, acceleration is zero.
The car's acceleration from the start of timing is 0 m/s².
